The Congress acknowledges California's rapid population growth and the environmental impacts, emphasizing the need for informed environmental policies and sustainable economic development through the California Urban Environmental Research and Education Center. The California Urban Environmental Research and Education Center aims to support sustainable economic development by assisting in converting defense resources to non-defense uses and incentivizing private sector involvement in solving environmental problems. The California Urban Environmental Research and Education Center aims to support sustainable economic development by converting defense resources to non-defense uses and encouraging private sector involvement in solving environmental problems. SEC. 2. CENTER. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency will support the California Urban Environmental Research and Education Center's development and expansion. If California State University, Hayward provides matching funds, cooperative agreements will be entered into to continue supporting the Center, with collaboration from other universities in the California State University system. The California State University, Hayward must guarantee matching funds for the Center's projects. Other universities in California can also join the Center under specific guidelines. The Center can have a Governing Board for the initial two-year period with members appointed by various California State University presidents. The Governing Board of the California State University, San Francisco, and California State University, Sonoma, will be determined by sitting members in consultation with university Presidents. The Executive Director will serve as chair for the first five years, with subsequent chairs elected from Board members. Duties include establishing membership criteria for the Center. The Center's Governing Board will establish criteria for membership, contribution requirements, fair representation guidelines, awarding of scholarships and grants, and advise the Executive Director on project management and grant administration. The Executive Director of the Center shall be appointed for a five-year term and shall annually submit the budget. The Executive Director must submit an annual budget to the Governing Board, including staff requirements and expenses. The Center's principal office is in northern California, with plans to establish a second office in southern California within two years. The Center's principal office is in northern California, with plans to establish a second office in southern California within two years. SEC. 3. FUNCTIONS. The Center's objective is to promote sustainable economic development in California through applied environmental research, education, and outreach. It aims to foster public-private partnerships, address environmental problems, and facilitate private sector development. The Center aims to bring together researchers from member universities and colleges to focus on California's environmental problems related to sustainable economic development. It supports research activities for data collection on various aspects of California's environment and dissemination of policy-oriented research findings. The Center focuses on sustainable economic development in California, conducting research and analysis on public policy implications, offering educational programs for policymakers, and utilizing electronic technology for knowledge dissemination. The Center conducts a national conference on ecology and sustainable economic development for business and labor leaders, provides access to expertise for policymakers at all levels, and aims to minimize duplication and waste. The Center focuses on minimizing duplication and waste in research programs, developing educational programs for sustainable economic development, and creating degree programs for individuals affected by defense spending cutbacks to become environmental professionals. The Center focuses on preparing minority students for environmental professions through enriched curriculum at baccalaureate and post-graduate levels. They also aim to develop a repository of information on environmental and economic development issues for easy access by private and public sector entities. The Center aims to establish a National Environmental Outreach Program to promote environmentally sound economic development and collaborate with research centers to transfer environmental technology to the private sector. They may also impose a fee for repository users to cover operational costs and support small, environmentally focused businesses. The Center aims to promote environmentally sound economic development and collaborate with research centers to transfer environmental technology to the private sector. They also assist small businesses in meeting environmental regulations and work with public and private sectors on alternative uses for military installations. The Center may provide scholarships for individuals studying in environmental fields at member universities, particularly those affected by the closing of military installations. The Center in California gives preference to individuals affected by military base closings for scholarships, fellowships, and research grants to promote sustainable economic development and research critical to their functions. The Center in California annually reports activities and budget needs to the Administrator. It can receive funds and property donations to further its activities, which are accounted for in annual reports. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The term ``Administrator'' refers to the head of the Environmental Protection Agency, and the term ``Center'' refers to the California Urban Environmental Research and Education Center established under this Act. Authorization of appropriations for the Administrator to provide funds to the California Urban Environmental Research and Education Center is set at $4,500,000 for fiscal year 1998 and as needed for fiscal years 1999 through 2002. Funds will remain available until expended, and the Center is encouraged to match these funds with contributions from State, local governments, and the private sector.
